column3: German: [ˈɡœtɪŋən] (listen); Low German: Chöttingen) is a university city in Lower Saxony
column4: Germany
column5: the capital of the eponymous district. It is run through by River Leine. At the start of 2017

column1: The origins of Göttingen lay in a village called Gutingi
column2: first mentioned in a document in 953 AD. The city was founded northwest of this village
column4: and adopted its name. In medieval times the city was a member of the Hanseatic League and hence a wealthy town.

column2: Göttingen is famous for its old university (Georgia Augusta
column4: which was founded in 1734 (first classes in 1737) and became the most visited university of Europe. In 1837
column5: seven professors protested against the absolute sovereignty of the kings of Hanover; they lost their offices
column6: but became known as the "Göttingen Seven". Its alumni include some well-known historical figures: the Brothers Grimm
column8: Wilhelm Eduard Weber and Georg Gervinus. Also
column9: German Chancellors Otto von Bismarck and Gerhard Schröder attended law school at the Göttingen University. Karl Barth held his first professorship here. Some of the most famous mathematicians in history

column2: Göttingen has developed its own quaint traditions. On the day they are awarded their doctorate degrees
column3: students are drawn in handcarts from the Great Hall to the Gänseliesel-Fountain in front of the Old Town Hall. There they have to climb the fountain and kiss the statue of the Gänseliesel (goose girl). This practice is actually forbidden
column4: but the law is not enforced. The statue is considered the most kissed girl in the world.

column1: Nearly untouched by Allied bombing in World War II
column2: the inner city of Göttingen is now an attractive place to live with many shops
column3: cafes and bars. For this reason
column4: many university students live in the inner city and give Göttingen a youthful feel. In 2003
column5: 45% of the inner city population was only between 18 and 30 years of age.

column2: Göttingen is noted for its production of optical and precision-engineered machinery
column3: being the seat of the light microscopy division of Carl Zeiss
column4: Inc.
column5: and a main site for Sartorius AG which specialises in bio-technology and measurement equipment—the region around Göttingen advertises itself as "Measurement Valley".

column1: Unemployment in Göttingen was 12.6% in 2003 and is now 7% (March 2014). The city's railway station to the west of the city centre is on Germany's main north–south railway.
Göttingen has two professional basketball teams; both the men's and women's teams play in the Basketball-Bundesliga. For the 2007–08 season
column2: both teams will play in the 1st division.

column1: The origins of Göttingen can be traced back to a village named Gutingi to the immediate south-east of the eventual city. The name of the village probably derives from a small stream
column3: that once flowed through it. Since the ending -ing denoted "living by"
column4: the name can be understood as "along the Gote". Archaeological evidence points towards a settlement as early as the 7th century. It is first historically mentioned in a document by the Holy Roman Emperor Otto I in 953 AD
column5: in which the emperor gives some of his belongings in the village to the Moritz monastery in Magdeburg. Archaeological findings point to extensive commercial relations with other regions and a developed craftsmanship in this early period.

column3: historically documented from the year 915 AD as a newly built fortress
column4: lying opposite Gutingi on a hill west of the River Leine. It was subsequently used as an Ottonian imperial palace
column5: with 18 visits of kings and emperors documented between 941 and 1025 AD. The last Holy Roman Emperor to use the fortress of Grona (said to have been fond of the location)
column6: Heinrich II (1002–1024)
column7: also had a church built in the neighbouring Gutingi
column8: dedicated to Saint Alban. The current church building that occupies this site

column1: The fortress then lost its function as a palace in 1025
column3: having retreated to it in ill health. It was subsequently used by the lords of Grone. The fortress was destroyed by the citizens of Göttingen between 1323 and 1329
column4: and finally razed to the ground by Duke Otto I during his feuds with the city of Göttingen in 1387.

column2: a trading settlement started to form at the river crossing of the Leine to the west of the village
column3: from which it took its name. It is this settlement that was eventually given city rights. The original village remained recognisable as a separate entity until about 1360
column4: at which time it was incorporated within the town's fortification.

column1: It is likely the present city was founded between 1150 and 1180

column5: and it has been proposed that the inception of the town followed a planned design. At this time
column6: the town was known by the name Gudingin or also Gotingen. Its inhabitants obeyed welfish ownership and ruling rights
column7: and the first Göttingen burghers are mentioned
column8: indicating that Göttingen was already organised as a true city. It was not
column11: but subject to the Welf dukes of Brunswick-Lüneburg. Henry the Elder (V) of Brunswick
column12: eldest son of Henry the Lion and brother of the Holy Roman Emperor Otto IV
column13: is given as the lord over Göttingen between 1201 and 1208. The original Welf residency in the town consisted of a farm building and the stables of the Welf dukes
column14: which occupied the oldest part of the city's fortifications built prior to 1250. In its early days
column15: Göttingen became involved in the conflicts of the Welfs with their enemies. The initial conflicts in the first decades of the 13th century benefited the burghers of Göttingen
column16: who were able to use the political and military situation to be courted by various parties
column17: and hence forcing the Welf town lords to make certain compromises with the town. In a document from 1232
column18: Duke Otto the Child gave the citizens of Göttingen the same rights which they had held at the time of his uncles Otto IV and Henry the Elder of Brunswick. These included privileges concerning self-governance of the town
column20: and trading facilitation. The document also promises that the town is not to fall into the hands of other powers. It is to be assumed that at this time Göttingen possessed a city council of burghers. The names of council members are first given in a document from 1247.

column1: The area secured by the initial fortification included the old market place
column4: St. Johannes (St John's) and St. Jacobi (St. James's)

column6: as well as the large Weender Straße
column7: Groner Straße and Rote Straße (red street). Outside of the fortification in front of the Geismar city gate lay the old village with the Church of St. Alban
column8: which was subsequently known as Geismarer altes Dorf (old Geismar village). This village was only to a limited extent under welfish control and thus could not be included in the town's privileges and fortification.

column1: The town was initially protected by a rampart
column2: as of the late 13th century then also by walls on top of the mound-like ramparts. Of these
column3: only one tower with a short stretch of the wall survives in the Turmstraße (tower street). The thus protected area included maximally 600 m by 600 m
column4: or about 25 hectares. This made it smaller than contemporary Hanover
column5: but larger than the neighbouring Welfish towns of Northeim
column6: Duderstadt and Hann. Münden.

column1: The Gote stream that flowed south of the walls of the town was connected to the River Leine via a channel at about this time and the waterway has since been known as the Leine Canal.
After the death of Otto the Child in 1257
column2: his sons Albert I of Brunswick (the Great) and Johann inherited their father's territories. Duke Albrecht I governed for his brother
column4: at first. Subsequently
column5: the brothers agreed to divide the territory between themselves in 1267
column6: effective 1269. The city of Göttingen went to Albert I
column7: and was inherited by his son Duke Albert II "the Fat" in 1286. Albert II chose Göttingen as his residence and moved into the Welf residency
column8: which he rebuilt into a fortress known as the Ballerhus
column9: after which the Burgstraße (fortress street) is named.

column1: Albert II attempted to gain further control over the economically and politically rapidly growing town by founding a new town (German: Neustadt) west of the original town
column2: across the Leine Canal and outside of the Groner City Gate. This competing settlement consisted of a single street
column4: with houses on either side of the street. The Duke
column5: however
column6: could not prevent Göttingen's westward expansion nor the success of the Göttingen City Council in effectively checking any hope of economic development in the Neustadt. The St. Marien Church (St. Mary's) was built to the south of the Neustadt which
column7: together with all adjoining farm buildings
column8: was given to the Teutonic Knights in 1318.

column1: After the failure of the new town
column2: the city council bought up the uncomfortable competition to the west in 1319 for three hundred Marks
column3: and obtained the promise from the Duke that he would not erect any fortress within a mile of the town.

column1: Two monasteries were also founded on the edge of the town at the end of the 13th century. To the east
column2: in the area of today's Wilhelmsplatz
column3: a Franciscan monastery was built as early as 1268
column4: according to the city chronicler Franciscus Lubecus. Since the Franciscans walked barefoot as part of their vow of poverty
column5: they were known colloquially as the barefoot people
column6: hence the name Barfüßerstraße (Barefoot People's Street) for the road that led to the monastery. In 1294
column7: Albert the Fat permitted the founding of a Dominican monastery along the Leine Canal opposite the Neustadt

column1: Jews settled in Göttingen in the late 13th century. On 1 March 1289
column2: the Duke gave the City Council permission to allow the first Jew
column4: to settle inside the town limits. The subsequent Jewish population lived predominantly close to St. James's Church on the Jüdenstraße.

column1: After Albert the Fat's death in 1318
column2: Göttingen passed to Otto the Mild (d. 1344)
column3: who ruled over both the "Principality of Göttingen" (German: Fürstentum Göttingen) and the territory of Brunswick. These dukes joined Göttingen and surrounding towns in battles against aristocratic knights in the surroundings of Göttingen
column4: in the course of which the citizens of Göttingen succeeded in destroying the fortress of Grone between 1323 and 1329
column5: as well as the fortress of Rosdorf. Since Otto the Mild died without leaving any children
column6: his brothers Magnus and Ernest divided the land between themselves. Ernest I received Göttingen
column7: the poorest of all the Welf principalities
column8: which was to remain separate from Brunswick for a long time to come. At this time
column9: the territory consisted of the regions formerly owned by Northeim
column14: Gieselwerder and half of Moringen. Not much is known about the rule of Duke Ernest I
column15: but it is generally assumed that he continued to fight against aristocratic knights.

column1: Ernest I was succeeded after his death in 1367 by his son Otto I of Göttingen (the Evil; German: der Quade) (d. 1394)
column2: who initially lived in the city's fortress and attempted to make it a permanent Welf residency. The epithet the Evil came from Otto I's incessant feuds. Breaking with the policies of his predecessors
column3: he frequently aligned himself with the aristocratic knights of the neighbourhood in battles against the cities
column4: whose growing power disturbed him. Under Otto the Evil
column5: Göttingen gained a large degree of independence. After losing control of the provincial court at the Leineberg to Göttingen in 1375
column6: Otto finally tried to impose his influence on Göttingen in 1387
column7: but with little success. In April 1387
column8: Göttingen's citizens stormed and destroyed the fortress within the city's walls. In retaliation
column9: Otto destroyed villages and farms in the town's surroundings. However
column10: Göttingen's citizens gained a victory over the Duke's army in a battle between the villages of Rosdorf and Grone
column11: under their leader Moritz of Uslar
column12: forcing Otto to acknowledge the independence of the town and its surrounding properties. 1387 thus marks an important turning point in the history of the town. Göttingen's relative autonomy was further strengthened under Otto's successor Otto II "the One-eyed" of Göttingen (German: Cocles/der Einäugige)
column13: not least because the Welf line of Brunswick-Göttingen died out with Otto II
column14: and the resulting questions surrounding his succession after his abdication in 1435 destabilized the regional aristocracy.

column1: After Duke Otto I of Göttingen relinquished his jurisdiction over Jews to the town of Göttingen in the years 1369–70
column3: and several bloody persecutions and evictions from the town followed. Between 1460 and 1599
column4: no Jews lived in Göttingen at all.

column1: The trend towards ever diminishing Welf influence over the town continued until the end of the 15th century
column2: although the town officially remains a Welf property. Nevertheless
column3: it is counted in some contemporaneous documents among the Imperial Free Cities.

column1: The 14th and 15th centuries thus represent a time of political and economic power expansion
column2: which is also reflected in the contemporary architecture. The expansion of the St. Johannis Church to a Gothic hall church began in the first half of the 14th century. As of 1330
column3: a Gothic structure also replaced the smaller St Nikolai Church (St. Nicholas's). After completion of the work on St. John's Church
column4: the rebuilding of St James's was begun in the second half of the 14th century. The original
column5: smaller church that preceded this building was probably initiated by Henry the Lion or his successor
column6: and functioned as a fortress chapel to the city fortress that lay immediately behind it. The representative old town hall was built between 1366 and 1444.

column2: the town's fortifications were rebuilt to encompass now also the new town and the old village. In the course of this construction work
column3: the four city gates were moved farther out
column4: and the town's area grew to roughly 75 hectares. The city council forged alliances with surrounding towns
column5: and Göttingen joined the Hanseatic League in 1351 (see below). Göttingen also gained Grona (currently Grone) and several other surrounding villages in the Leine Valley.

column1: The reason for the progressive power increase in the late Middle Ages was the growing economic importance of the town. This depended largely on its good connection to the north–south trade route
column2: particularly the north–south trade route that followed the Leine Valley
column3: which greatly aided the local textile industry in particular. Next to the guild of linen weavers
column4: the guild of wool weavers gained in importance. The wool for the weaving originated in the immediate surroundings of the town
column5: where up to 3000 sheep and 1500 lambs were kept. Woollen cloth was successfully exported all the way to the Netherlands and Lübeck. From 1475
column6: textile production was augmented by the addition of new weavers who brought novel weaving techniques to Göttingen and consolidated the position of the town as a textile exporter for three generations. Only at the end of the 16th century did the decline of the local textile industry occur when Göttingen could not compete anymore with cheap English textiles.

column1: Göttingen's traders also profited from the important trade route between Lübeck and Frankfurt am Main. Göttingen's market became important beyond the region. Traders from other regions would come in great numbers four times a year. Göttingen also joined the Hanseatic League
column2: to the first meeting of which it was invited in 1351. Göttingen's relationship with the Hanseatic League remained distant
column4: Göttingen enjoyed the economic connections of the League
column5: but it did not want to get involved in the politics of the alliance. Göttingen only became a paying member in 1426
column6: and left as early as 1572.

column3: Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg and prince-elector of Hanover. During the Napoleonic period

column9: the Kingdom of Hanover was dissolved and Göttingen became part of the Prussian Province of Hanover. The Province of Hanover was disestablished in 1946.

column1: In 1854 the city was connected to the new Hanoverian Southern Railway. Today

Göttingen housed the top math-physics faculty in the world
column4: almost all Jews
column5: who became known as the Göttingen eight. Their members included Leó Szilárd and Edward Teller. This faculty was not tolerable to the Reich
column6: however
column7: and the University of Göttingen suffered greatly as a result. The Göttingen eight were expelled
column8: and these men were forced to emigrate to the West in 1938. Szilárd and Teller went on to become key members of the Manhattan Project team. Ironically
column9: the Nazi insistence on a "German physics" prevented German scientists from applying Albert Einstein's breakthrough insights to physics

column14: a process which has continued into the 21st century.The population of Göttingen supported Hitler and Nazism from an early date. As early as 1933 the Theaterplatz (Theater Square) was renamed Adolf-Hitlerplatz
column15: and by the end of World War II 70 streets had been renamed in reference to the Nazi regime or military topics. The absorption of Nazi culture into the everyday life of the citizens of Göttingen has been documented by historian David Imhoof. The synagogue in Göttingen was destroyed during Kristallnacht on 9 November 1938. Many of the Jews were killed in Nazi German extermination camps. Also
column16: there was a concentration camp for adolescents in Moringen

column2: Canadian and American  air raids on Nazi Germany
column3: Göttingen suffered comparatively little damage. Only about 2.1% of the city was destroyed. Beginning in July 1944
column4: the air raids were sometimes heavier
column5: but these mainly hit the area of the main railway station last on 7 April 1945. The historic old town of Göttingen remained practically undamaged.

column2: a historic half-timbered house was destroyed in a 1945 air-raid and the exterior was not properly reconstructed until the 1980s. Two of the churches (Paulinerkirche and Johanniskirche) in the old town
column3: and several buildings of the university
column4: were heavily damaged. The Institute of Anatomy and 57 residential buildings
column5: especially in Untere Masch Street in the centre of the city
column6: were completely destroyed. Overall
column7: only about 107 deaths were caused by the air raids
column9: the neighbouring cities of Hanover and Brunswick experienced a much greater impact from the bombing raids. Kassel was destroyed several times.

column1: Because the city had many hospitals
column2: those hospitals had to take care of up to four thousand wounded Wehrmacht soldiers and airmen during World War II. Göttingen was also fortunate in that before troops of the U.S. Army arrived in Göttingen on 8 April 1945
column3: all of the Wehrmacht's combat units had departed from this area
column4: hence Göttingen experienced no heavy ground fighting
column5: artillery bombardments or other major combat.

column1: In a reform in 1973 the district of Göttingen was enlarged by incorporating the dissolved districts of Duderstadt and Hannoversch Münden.
Prior to the period of German romanticism
column2: a group of German poets that had studied at this university between 1772 and 1776
column3: formed the Göttinger Hainbund or "Dichterbund" ('circle of poets'). Being disciples of Klopstock
column4: they revived the folksong and wrote lyric poetry of the Sturm und Drang period. Their impact was essential on romanticism in the German-speaking area and on folklore in general.

column2: the town has been associated with the revival of interest in the music of George Frideric Handel. The Göttingen International Handel Festival is held each summer with performances in the Stadthalle Göttingen and a number of churches.

column1: A town council with 24 councillors dates from the 12th century. In 1319 this council took control of the new city district (Neustadt) just in front of the wall. The council election took place on the Mondays following Michaelmas (September 29). Starting in 1611 all citizens were able to elect the 24 councillors. Previously this right was restricted and depended on income and profession. Afterwards
column2: the council elected the Bürgermeister (mayor). In 1669 the number of councillors was reduced to 16
column3: and later to 12. In 1690 the city administration was reorganised again. Then the council consisted of the judge
column4: two mayors
column5: the city lawyer (Syndikus)
column6: the secretary and eight councillors. All of these were appointed by the government. During the Napoleonic era the mayor was called Maire
column7: and there was also a city council. In 1831 there was another reform of the constitution and the administration. The title of the mayor changed to Oberbürgermeister. In the following decades there were more reforms to the city administration
column8: which reflected the constitutional and territorial reorganisations of Germany. During the Third Reich the mayor was appointed by the Nazi Party.

column1: The coat of arms of Göttingen shows in the top half three silver towers with red roofs on a field of blue. The lateral towers possess four windows each and are crowned by golden crosses. Around the central tower are four silver balls. The city towers represent the status as a city which has been granted certain rights. In the bottom field is a golden lion on a red field. This lion represents the lion of the Welf dynasty
column2: which in its various branches ruled the area of Göttingen for 850 years. This coat of arms was first documented in 1278. The city has sometimes used a simpler one
column3: consisting of a black capital "G" on a golden field
column4: topped with a crown.
